distances module

A module to calculate the distance between two points on the Earth using the Haversine formula.

class distances.Coordinates(*, lat: float, lon: float)

Bases: BaseModel

A Pydantic model to represent geographic coordinates.

lat

Latitude of the point, degrees.

Type:

float

lon

Longitude of the point, degrees.

Type:

float

lat: float
lon: float
model_config: ClassVar[ConfigDict] = {}
model_fields: ClassVar[dict[str, FieldInfo]] = {'lat': FieldInfo(annotation=float, required=True), 'lon': FieldInfo(annotation=float, required=True)}
distances.haversine_distance(coord1: Coordinates, coord2: Coordinates) → float

Calculate the great-circle distance between two points on the Earth using the Haversine formula.

Parameters:

  • coord1 (Coordinates) – The latitude and longitude of the first point as a Coordinates object.

  • coord2 (Coordinates) – The latitude and longitude of the second point as a Coordinates object.

Returns:

The distance between the two points in kilometers, rounded to 4 decimal places.

Return type:

float

Notes

The Haversine formula is an equation important in navigation, giving great-circle distances between two points on a sphere from their longitudes and latitudes. This implementation uses the formula to calculate distances between two points on Earth, providing an approximation that does not account for ellipsoidal effects.

Examples

>>> coord1 = Coordinates(lat=52.5200, lon=13.4050)  # Berlin, Germany
>>> coord2 = Coordinates(lat=48.8566, lon=2.3522)  # Paris, France
>>> haversine_distance(coord1, coord2)
878.9012
